posts.post_content: If you're against an Infect deck, this card is pure gold (she said as though it were not glaringly obvious). Sure, she needs protection from various types of removal, destruction, and direct damage, but so do most good permanents. Of course, unless you're running a deck that also takes advantage of her abilities when you're *not* raging against the tyranny of Phyrexia, you're going to want to leave her in your sideboard.

posts.post_content:
@Falgren  
  
Her ability that removes infect from opponents' creatures is a continuous one, so even if someone uses tainted strike to give their creature infect, it will immediately be lost again once state based actions are checked (right after the spell resolves). There is no mentioning of an EtB trigger.
posts.html:
@Falgren

Her ability that removes infect from opponents' creatures is a continuous one, so even if someone uses tainted strike to give their creature infect, it will immediately be lost again once state based actions are checked (right after the spell resolves). There is no mentioning of an EtB trigger.

Posted By: Superllama12 (6/8/2011 8:17:41 PM)

posts.post_content:
@ MindEcho and Sir\_Thom:  
As long as she's on the battlefield, you can neither proliferate any preexisting -1/-1 counters on her controller's creatures, nor any poison counters that player already had. That's because proliferating them is to place one more counter on each of the chosen permanents and/or have that player get one more poison counter. She forbids that.  
  
Effectively, she will turn creatures with infect into normal-damage creatures (incredibly unimpressive for their mana costs) and will make creatures with wither unable to deal visible damage to creatures. Abilities that trigger on damage being dealt, lifelink, deathtouch etc. will still see that damage though.  
  
Her third ability will remove infect from any creature that naturally has it, even if it enters the battlefield after [Melira](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=194274).  
  
When interacting with effects that grant infect to a creature, apply them in timestamp order. Last to be created wins.  
*For example... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)*
posts.html:
@ MindEcho and Sir_Thom:
As long as she's on the battlefield, you can neither proliferate any preexisting -1/-1 counters on her controller's creatures, nor any poison counters that player already had. That's because proliferating them is to place one more counter on each of the chosen permanents and/or have that player get one more poison counter. She forbids that.

Effectively, she will turn creatures with infect into normal-damage creatures (incredibly unimpressive for their mana costs) and will make creatures with wither unable to deal visible damage to creatures. Abilities that trigger on damage being dealt, lifelink, deathtouch etc. will still see that damage though.

Her third ability will remove infect from any creature that naturally has it, even if it enters the battlefield after Melira.

When interacting with effects that grant infect to a creature, apply them in timestamp order. Last to be created wins.
For example... (see all)

Posted By: Ava_Adore (5/19/2011 5:29:49 PM)
Rating:

@BastianQoU: No, Melira does prevent the counters from being placed on Etched Monstrosity. I hate quoting rules because I hate sounding like a know-it-all, but this is somewhat important to learn due to Melira's abilities:

121.5. If a spell or ability refers to a counter being “placed” on a permanent, it means putting a counter on that permanent while it’s on the battlefield, or that permanent entering the battlefield with a counter on it.

Somebody get Midnight Banshee on her side, by the way. Those two will do work.
